title: OAuth Integration (GitHub + Google)
description:
Implement OAuth 2.0 login with GitHub and Google using Arctic library.

FLOW:
1. User clicks Login with GitHub/Google
2. Redirect to provider
3. Callback receives code
4. Exchange for tokens
5. Fetch user profile
6. Create/update user in DB (default role: viewer)
7. Issue httpOnly session cookie
8. Redirect to app

REQUIREMENTS:
- Secure token storage (httpOnly cookies)
- Session management with refresh
- Logout functionality
- CSRF protection

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- GitHub login works E2E
- Google login works E2E
- Session persists across refresh
- Logout clears session
- New users get 'viewer' role

TESTS:
- OAuth callback with mock provider
- Session validation
- User create/update logic
- Logout clears cookies
close_reason: Implemented OAuth (GitHub/Google), invite system, session management, database schema

title: Invite Link System
description:
Create and manage permanent invite links for onboarding users.

REQUIREMENTS:
- Generate 16-char URL-safe tokens
- Store hashed tokens (SHA-256, not plaintext)
- Assign role (viewer/operator) on create
- Link OAuth with pending invite
- Track usage count
- Support revocation

API ENDPOINTS:
- POST /api/invites - Create (Admin+)
- GET /api/invites - List (Admin+)
- DELETE /api/invites/:id - Revoke (Admin+)
- GET /api/invites/:token/validate - Check valid (public)
- POST /api/invites/:token/accept - Accept after OAuth

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- Tokens are 16-char URL-safe
- Tokens stored as SHA-256 hash
- Creator specifies role
- Usage count increments
- Revoked invites rejected
- User gets assigned role

TESTS:
- Token generation uniqueness
- Hash verification
- Role assignment on accept
- Revocation blocks future use
- Rate limiting on validation
close_reason: Implemented OAuth (GitHub/Google), invite system, session management, database schema

title: Permission Enforcement
description:
Implement role-based permission checking throughout application.

PERMISSION MATRIX:
- Owner: Everything
- Admin: All except workspace deletion, ownership transfer
- Operator: Send commands, create sessions, claim sessions
- Viewer: Read-only, own UI state

REQUIREMENTS:
- Middleware for API route protection
- WebSocket message permission checking
- Helper functions: canSendKeys(), canManageUsers(), canClaim(), etc.
- Consistent 403 errors with reason

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- All API routes check permissions
- All WebSocket actions check permissions
- Viewers cannot send keys (server enforced)
- Operators cannot manage users
- Admins cannot delete workspace

TESTS:
- Permission check for each role × each action
- Middleware blocks unauthorized
- Error messages clear and consistent
close_reason: Implemented permission enforcement: core functions, role validation, claim checks, WebSocket permissions, Hono middleware, 45 unit tests

title: Tmux Session Bridge
description:
Bridge tmux sessions to application - read output, send commands, list sessions.

CORE INTERFACE:
interface TmuxBridge {
  listSessions(): Promise<TmuxSession[]>
  capturePane(session: string, pane?: string): Promise<string>
  sendKeys(session: string, keys: string): Promise<void>
  getScrollback(session: string, lines: number): Promise<string>
}

REQUIREMENTS:
- List all tmux sessions with metadata
- Capture pane output with ANSI codes (tmux capture-pane -p -e)
- Poll at 5 FPS (200ms interval)
- Send keys to sessions (operator+ only)
- Handle scrollback buffer (-S flag)
- Detect session creation/destruction

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- List matches tmux list-sessions
- Capture returns ANSI colors
- Send keys executes correctly
- Screen clears handled
- Works with session:window.pane format

TESTS:
- Mock tmux for unit tests
- Integration with real tmux
- ANSI escape preservation
- Error handling for missing sessions
